author: faraz3920
content:
Hello is there a way to generate a certificate of proof that a transaction occurred on the ethereum blockchain.

I want to monitor a account for incoming eth perform some offchain computation based on the amount of eth received in the account.   Is there a “certificate” that the block chain can generate such that I don’t have to run a full eth node.

author: faraz3920
content: I know about the “don’t trust verify” mantra. I am curious to know how will running a local node work in ETH2 for cases where one just wants to verify authencity of a transaction post consensus. Will I need 32 eth for this ?

author: domotheus
content: You won't need 32 ETH to run a full node after the merge. As for the certificate, my best guess would be a merkle proof that shows the transaction is indeed included in a specific block by checking against the transactionsRoot block header, which can be verified by a light node that only syncs headers

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> You do not need 32 ETH to run a full node. You only need to do this to run a validator

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> Anyone can run a full node and it is very cheap to do so. Yes you can use it to verify that a transaction has occured.
